history.content:
I'm currently in 189, and I haven't taken EE126 yet; that being said, I definitely plan to take it next semester. Taking 189 has made me realise that having an advanced understanding of probability (beyond CS70) and linear algebra (beyond 54) is essential to understanding further techniques, so I would recommend taking EE126 if possible (I've also heard some good things about the class).

-------

If you are truly interested in ML, you should not be skimping on any math. Take the hardest classes you can possibly take as they will pay dividends in the form of a stronger math background in the future.

I'm currently in 189, and I haven't taken EE126 yet; that being said, I definitely plan to take it next semester. Taking 189 has made me realise that having an advanced understanding of probability (beyond CS70) and linear algebra (beyond 54) is essential to understanding further techniques, so I would recommend taking EE126 if possible (I've also heard some good things about the class).
You should take 126. There's a reason we offer it.

children.subject: 126 is a good class, but I don't think it's for everyone. Personally, as someone who's not really that interested in ML, I found the class way too intense, and I had to drop it. But if you're sure ML is the way to go, then definitely do it.
Since you mentioned 134, I took it and regretted it and wish I had taken 126 instead as it seemed much more useful.

For the record: I've taken 188 and 189, and I'm currently taking 126 and 127.

127 vs 189? I think 127 is a harder course than 189, but remember that also depends on the teacher for the course. Most people I know take 189 before taking 127. (also note that 188 is largely unrelated to 126, 127, and 189.) 127 is more general than 189 -- machine learning uses convex optimization as an application.

127 vs 126? They are completely unrelated. 126 covers probability, 127 covers convex optimization and linear algebra.

126 vs 134? 126 is the harder course, because it covers more topics, is more accelerated, and has the sharpest cs students taking it. It is very competitive. It will take a substantial amount of time. The hws are weekly and take 10 hours each for me (not alone, with working with other students). if you have the time, go for it.

I have found all of these courses to be amazing. You can't go wrong with any. Take all if you're in the AI/ML track.
Any downsides to taking 127 before 189? I wanted to take 188 before 189, so I planned to do 127 alongside 188.

I think you should be fine. I took both 189 and I'm taking 127 right now, and while 127 mentions some concepts taught in 189 such as support vector machines, it doesn't really build on top of 189 that much. You might be familiar with some of the things taught in the beginning of 127 if you took 189 (i.e. SVD), but they're not too difficult to learn.
is EE 126 necessary for EE 127, or is taking 127 a reasonable pursuit (assuming having taken 54 and 70, but not cs 188 or cs 189 or stat 134)

Considering that a bunch of CS theory related courses are right at the same time (EE 127, CS 276, CS 294), if probability is not your highest priority, I would suggest taking Stat 134. You only have so many semesters here at Cal.

history.content: I'd probably have to drop a breadth class that isn't required but I'm interested in to accommodate the workload of EE126, is it worth the time?
history.subject: Is EE126 worth the intensity, or is Stat 134 sufficient to give background for ML?
